title: Husband who shot wife dead at dentist's office is sentenced to life in prison
text:
A husband who shot and killed his estranged wife at the dentist's office where she worked after she filed a restraining order against him has been sentenced to life in prison.

Harry Clint Weaver, 64, was convicted of first-degree murder on Tuesday in the death of his estranged wife Kelly Weaver, 52, in Colonial Hills, Tennessee.

On the morning of February 13, Harry burst into the office where his wife worked at David A Guy Dentistry with a gun and screamed: 'Kelly, I told you I was going to get you!' before grabbing her by the hair and trying to pull her to the back of the building.

As co-workers tried to intervene, Harry opened fire, fatally shooting his wife in the head.

Harry Clint Weaver, 64, has been sentenced to life in prison for shooting dead his estranged wife at the dentist office where she worked in Colonial Hills, Tennessee. The defendant is pictured (left) in court during his sentencing on Tuesday

Harry Weaver (left) and his wife Kelly Weaver, 52, (right) were going through a divorce at the time of the fatal shooting

Witnesses said Harry then turned the gun on another employee and fired at her but missed.

A patient at the office, Larry Seagroves, who had a concealed carry permit, shot Harry several times and held him at gunpoint until police arrived.

While they waited for police, Harry taunted Kelly's co-workers, saying: 'She's dead! She's dead!'

Harry spent two weeks in the hospital recovering from his gunshot wounds before being booked into jail.

The couple were reportedly going through a divorce at the time of the fatal incident and Kelly obtained a restraining order against Harry months earlier.

On the morning of February 13, Harry burst into the office where his wife worked at David A Guy Dentistry with a gun and screamed: 'Kelly, I told you I was going to get you!' before grabbing her by the hair and trying to pull her to the back of the building (pictured)

Harry pleaded not guilty to a slew of charges in August before striking a plea deal with prosecutors ahead of Tuesday's hearing in Sullivan County Criminal Court.

He ultimately pleaded guilty to murder, three counts of aggravated assault, reckless endangerment and aggravated domestic assault.

Sullivan County Assistant District Attorney Kaylin Render said prosecutors offered the plea deal to avoid a potentially lengthy trial.

Weaver won't be eligible for parole for at least 51 years. By then he would be 115 years old.

'He was given a life sentence ... with the blessings of [Kelly's] family,' Render said.
